PV928Q94.title: 2021_Shikwambana_Observations of Emissions and the Influence of Meteorological Conditions during.pdf

sentences.sentence: sentinel-5p was launched in october 2017 with a mission to carry out global atmospheric measurements (for air quality, o3, uv radiation, and climate monitoring and forecasting) with a high spatio-temporal resolution

sentinel-5p carries the tropomi (tropomi) sensor, which provides high-resolution measurements in the ultraviolet (uv), visible (vis), near-infrared (nir), and shortwave-infrared (swir) part of the spectrum
in this study, tropomi was used to map the spatial distribution of co over the periods of the wildfire observations at each study area
3.3. merra-2 the merra, version 2 (merra-2), provides data from 1980 to the present

merra-2 was introduced to replace and extend the original merra dataset , which ended in february 2016. it was produced using version 5.12.4 of the goddard earth observing system model (geos) data assimilation system (das)
a detailed description and data assimilation of merra-2 is described by
bc is derived from merra-2 and is one of the byproducts of biomass burning
in this study, we use merra-2 data to study the time series of bc column burden before, during, and after the wildfire disasters at each study area
3.4. airs the airs (airs) is a satellite that gathers the infrared energy emitted from the earth's surface and atmosphere globally to provide t and h2o measurements
airs provides atmospheric t profiles with an average accuracy of 1 k in 1 km (km) layers in the troposphere, humidity profiles to a 10% accuracy, and surface ts with an average accuracy of 0.5 k
more details on airs can be found in

across the study sites, the results also showed widely distributed co, as measured by sentinel-5p tropomi

L2UP4CMY.title: 2020_Filonchyk_Impact Assessment of COVID-19 on Variations of SO2, NO2, CO and AOD over East.pdf

sentences.sentence: so2 (so2) and no2 (no2) data so2 (so2) and no2 (no2) emission data obtained from omi (omi) on board the aura satellite launched in 2004 as part of the nasa eos (earth observation system) were used, which performed measurements of solar radiation reflected by the atmosphere and the earth's surface in the range from 270 to 500 nm and with a spectral resolution of 0.5 nm
in the omi mode, designed for shooting on a global scale, the pixel size when shooting in the nadir direction is 13 × 24 km along and across the shooting strip, respectively (levelt et al 2006)

as for no2, the omi instrument allowed to determine the total no2 content in the vertical column of the atmosphere as the total number of no2 molecules between the earth's surface and the tropopause per unit area (boersma et al 2004)
in this study, we used daily level 3 aura/omi so2 and no2 data products with a spatial resolution of 0.25 × 0.25 to study so2 and no2 emission in the hubei province
omi level 3 so2 and no2 data from nasa ges disc archive

airs (airs) introduces the grating spectrometer aboard aqua satellite, launched on may 4, 2002. the device was designed to support climate research and improve weather forecasting, and to display the concentration of a number of gases in the atmosphere, including h2o, co2, co, o3 and ch4

the main instrument of the complex is the airs infrared spectrometer, which has 2378 spectral channels and is capable of recording the intensity of outgoing thermal radiation in the ranges 3.74-4.61 m (2169-2674 cm-1), 6.20-8.22 m (1217-1613 cm-1), 8.815.4 m (649-1136 cm-1) with high spectral resolution (/) 1200 and a 13.5 km footprint at nadir (aumann et al 2003; pagano et al 2003; 2011)

the most efficient co extraction process in the middle airs troposphere is from 300 to 500 hpa (9-5.5 km); therefore, data from a height of 400 hpa (7 km) will be used in this work, and co data will be extracted globally in day and nighttime under clear and cloudy sky conditions (warner et al 2007; xiong et al 2008)
airs co products were obtained from goddard earth sciences data and information services center (ges/disc)
as a component of the nasa eos, moderate resolution imaging sectroradiometer (modis) on terra and aqua satellites provides level 2 aerosol products

due to the fact that the aqua satellite crossing the equator close to the aura satellite crossing time, it was decided to use aerosol optical depth (aod) data obtained by the modis-aqua satellite with a spatial resolution of 10 km and with the quality flag of at least 2 (qa = 2 and 3)

based on previous studies, the modis seasonal observation cycle is reported to be consistent with ground based observations, including the aerosol robotic network (aeronet) sun and sky radiance measurements (kim et al 2007)
the uncertainty of modis aod is 0.05 0.20 × aodaeronet (sayer et al 2013) and 0.05 0.15 × aodaeronet (levy et al 2013) over the land
modis aod data was obtained from nasa's level-1 and atmosphere archive and distribution system (laads) distributed active archive center (daac)
1 shows the average spatial distribution of modis aod for the first quarter (including january, february, and march) of 2019 and 2020. one of the possible causes of fig
1. spatial distribution of aod at 550 nm from modis

in addition, high coastal aod can be the result of strong emissions from ships, as well as long-range aerosol transport from north china plain and strong hygroscopic growth of aerosol due to high relative humidity, especially in the south region (huang et al 2018; ahmed et al 2020)
2. spatial distribution of planetary boundary layer (pbl) so2 from omi

3), the main sources were combustion processes (heating, power generation, engine operation of cars and ships), high no2 concentrations were similar to so2, which are located in highly urbanized areas such as beijing, tianjin, hangzhou, shanghai, shijiazhuang, nanjing
3. spatial distribution of tropospheric no2 from omi
modis and airs instrument on the aqua satellite and omi on the aura satellite collect data on aod, co and so2 and no2 in the troposphere of east china
4. spatial distribution of co at 400 hpa from airs

Z8JEGZB9.title: 2020_Yeditha_Forecasting of extreme flood events using different satellite precipitation.pdf

sentences.sentence: in the past, several precipitation products such as trmm (trmm), precipitation estimation from remotely sensed information using artificial neural networks (persiann), climate hazards group infrared precipitation with station data (chirps), gpms (gpm), and integrated multi-satellite retrievals gpm (imerg) have been successfully used in several applications such as streamflow modeling, water quality modeling, the rise of ocean tides, and others

similarly, daily streamflow estimation using trmm precipitation product was carried out for the congo basin using a semi-distributed hydrological model.14 the results of this study showed the capabilities of trmm datasets in capturing the timing and seasonality of flow
for this purpose, we have developed wavelet-based neural network models using satellite precipitation products such as trmm_3b42rtv7 and persiann as precipitation drivers
metrological and climatic parameters of imd, persiann, and trmm datasets for the vamsadhara river basin along with coverage area of the catchment

parameters max precipitation (mm) total annual precipitation (mm/year) area(km2) min t (centigrade) max t (c) total annual streamflow (m3/sec) imd 129.92 1231 basin vamsadara persiann 155.18 1979.9 10 442 7 33 89.33 trmm 146.96 1388.6 a ground-based observed indian meteorological department (imd) dataset
, trmm_3b42rtv7 and persiann data
trmm_3b42rtv7 products were developed by nasa and are available at a spatial resolution of 0.25 by 0.25 and temporal resolution of 3 h

the data range of the trmm_3b42rtv7 data is from march 2000 to march 2013. we have downloaded the trmm_3b42rtv7 dataset from , persiann datasets were derived using the infrared brightness t from the global geostationary satellites through neural network models

the imd rainfall product has a spatial resolution of 0.25 × 0.25 and was available from 1901 to 2018.39 for this study, we have only considered the data from march 2000 to 2013. the grid-based rainfall data from trmm_3b42rtv7, persiann, and imd were transformed into average areal precipitation using the thiessen polygon approach in arcgis

in this study, the accuracy of two satellite precipitation products persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 were evaluated with imd datasets for the period 14 years, ie 2000-2013. the metrics used in this work are the probability of detection (pod) and false alarm ratio (far)

study, imd datasets are the true values obtained from ground-based rain gauges; persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 data are satellitederived datasets used for assessing their capabilities to forecast streamflow
figure 2 represents the cumulative distributive function of imd, persiann, and trmm_3b42rtv7 data during the entire period in the study area
2. however, the trmm_3b42rtv7 dataset is also having a similar pattern of cdf as obtained using imd data
referring to table ii, trmm_3b42rtv7 data has more hit percentage than persiann
however, the percentage of false alarm is comparatively high in trmm_3b42rtv7 than the persiann datasets, leading to higher values of far (0.48)
(a, b, c, d), (e, f, g, h), and (i, j k, l) represent the models developed with imd, persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 datasets, respectively

4. forecasting capabilities of the developed model for the years 2008 (a), 2009 (b), 2010 (c), and 2011 (d) with imd (red), persiann (yellow), and trmm_3b42rtv7 (blue) datasets as inputs compared with observed streamflow (violet)
analysis of results from models using trmm_3b42rtv7 precipitation as forcing data to show that the wt-ffbp-nn produces better results compared to the other models
it is important to note that using the trmm_3b42rtv7 models, the performance of the benchmark models were poor results when compared to the results obtained using imd and persiann data

for example, the mlr model with trmm_3b42rtv7 produces results having r2 = 0.51, whereas the same model resulted in r2 = 0.811 and 0.672 when trmm_3b42rtv7 and imd were used as the precipitation forcing

now, comparing the results obtained from wt-ffbp-nn when different precipitation datasets show that the persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 based models produced similar results obtained from imd based wt-ffbp-nn models
for example, the imd based model produced flood estimates having r2 = 0.84, whereas persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 based model resulted in r2 = 0.78 and 0.86, respectively

similarly comparing the results obtained from the wt-ffbp-nn model for a two-day head forecast, imd based model yielded results with r2 = 0.775, whereas persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 based models resulted in higher r2 = 0.782 and 0.81 for the validation stage
error components of extreme flood events (>95% probability) for the best model (wt-ffbp-nn) using imd, persiann, and trmm precipitation datasets with respect to observed peak flood

metrics (m3/s) rmse mae std imd 314.17 227.55 265.15 data persiann 332.93 228.36 292.32 trmm 356.31 238.34 336.61 from the observations, it is clear that the satellite-based precipitation datasets can be used as an alternative for ground-based rain gauge data where the data are scarce
for the other three years, the performance of the imd based and persiann based models were close to the observed, whereas the trmm based model was either over- or under-predicting the flood peaks
the results reveal that the persiann and trmm_3b42rtv7 based wt-ffbp-nn model produced similar results to that obtained from the imd based model

overall, the above results reveal that the satellite precipitation products such as trmm_3b42rtv7 and persiann can be reliably used for forecasting extreme flood events and therefore can be potentially used in real-time flood forecasting systems
5. correlation of wt-ffbp-nn model for imd, persiann, and trmm_3b42rtv7 as inputs with the observed flood for forecasting of flood for 1 day ahead to 7 days ahead
in the first part of the study, the precipitation products trmm_3b42rtv7 and persiann were evaluated with respect to the ground-based imd data

sentences.sentence: 8-day composites of chlorophyll a concentrations from modis aqua at 4 km resolution are used to determine the biological activity close to the mooring site
monthly precipitation rate from january to december 2013 is available from the trmm (trmm) on a 0.25 × 0.25 grid
trmm precipitation (in mm h1) is plotted from 0n to 15n along 38w in 2013. the white dashed line corresponds to the location of the mooring at 8n
in 2013, at 8n, 38w, the itcz is present during the months of august to september as shown by the highest precipitation from trmm (fig
the comparison of the daily trmm precipitation of 2013 indicates that the month of september is not significantly different from any other month of the rainy season, using a wilcoxon rank-sum test
as no biological parameter is measured at 8n, 38w, we use the chlorophyll a concentration from modis
chlorophyll a (mg m3) data are from modis

modis data exhibit a peak of chlorophyll over 0.2 mg m3 at 8n, 38w in september 2013. the advection of the amazon plume is visible from the modis image in september with the highest chlorophyll concentrations near the amazon mouth that decrease eastward during the water transport within the necc
we acknowledge the trmm mission scientists and associated nasa personnel for production of these data, the oscar project office for providing the ocean surface current analyses

AFY9JUN3.title: 2020_Koster_Using a Simple Water Balance Framework to Quantify the Impact of Soil Moisture.pdf

sentences.sentence: in essence, the analysis below utilizes a full atmospheric reanalysis (merra-2; section 2a) to characterize the behavior of both the land surface and its meteorological drivers, and it then uses this characterization as the basis for a simple water balance framework that can produce estimates of evapotranspiration and air t at subseasonal leads (sections 2b and 2c)

the merra-2 reanalysis the merra, version 2 (merra-2), produced by the global modeling and assimilation office (gmao) at the national aeronautics and space administration's goddard space flight center (nasa gsfc), is a stateof-the-art atmospheric reanalysis that provides a comprehensive and self-consistent picture of atmospheric and land surface fields over the period 1980-present (gelaro et al 2017)

merra-2 combines a wealth of conventional and satellite-based measurements (mccarty et al 2016) together within a global atmosphere-land surface modeling environment that serves to translate in space and time the information contained in the observations and also to impose additional physical constraints on the evolution of the meteorological fields

merra-2, unique among existing atmospheric reanalyses in its utilization of aerosol information (randles et al 2016), has been evaluated extensively against independent observational datasets (bosilovich et al 2015)
the present analysis uses daily-averaged merra-2 data on a 0.58 latitude 3 0.6258 longitude grid

the precipitation falling on the land surface during the merra-2 integration included corrections from rain gauge networks (reichle et al 2017), which are accordingly built into merra-2's et and w fields

each black dot represents data from merra-2 at a sample location for a single day between 16 jun and 16 jul during the period 1980-99. the red curve shows the binned fit to the data; linear extrapolation is used for soil moisture values lying outside the range captured by the red curve

rather, it is simply estimated (2) (3) (4) by plotting daily merra-2 values of w and let/rnet against each other on a scatterplot and then determining the piecewise linear function that connects 10 binned averages of let/rnet
similar curves were successfully derived from merra-2 data for the flash drought analysis of koster et al (2019), although without the normalization of et by net radiation in that application
(5), allowing the calculation of et with the simple model when the precipitation and net radiation forcing are perfectly known (from merra-2)

make this assumption here because merra-2 data holdings do not include information on moisture flux between the root zone and deeper layers, which precludes the use of the root zone as the control volume in the water balance analysis
figure 1b illustrates, for the same location and day of year, the corresponding estimation of the soil moisturerunoff ratio relationship fq(w) from merra-2 data
as a simple test, we apply (4) to merra-2 data during each may of 1999-2015, using the framework outlined in fig
soil moistures were initialized on 1 may with values for that day from the merra-2 product, and eq
(4) was then used with daily merra-2 precipitation and net radiation data for that may to update the soil moistures over the course of the month
(5) we then compared the et estimates so obtained directly with the et product in merra-2 for that period

the top panel of figure 3 shows a map, over the continental united states, of the square of the correlation coefficient r2 between the 17 (one for each year between 1999 and 2015) 15-day et averages estimated in this fashion and the corresponding averages computed directly from the merra-2 et product
the bottom panel of figure 3 shows the corresponding map of the rmse of the evapotranspiration estimates relative to the merra-2 values

3. (top) the square of the correlation coefficient (r2) between 15-day-average et values from merra-2 and the corresponding et estimates produced by the simple model when the meteorological forcing (precipitation and net radiation) is itself taken from merra-2. the daily et values were averaged over 16-30 may (for each year during 1999-2015); the simple model was integrated forward starting from soil moisture conditions on 1 may
(4) to produce our projet estimates for the 1999-2015 forecast period (see section 2d) after deriving the functional forms fe(w) and fq(w) from independent (1980-98) merra-2 data

2b, we can initialize the simple water balance model with a soil moisture value for, say, 2005 (taken from merra-2 2005 holdings) and then integrate eq

) notice also that the projet estimate relies solely on the initial soil moisture, the estimated fe(w) and fq(w) relationships, and the suite of forcing time series taken from the independent time period-no information from the forecast period itself goes into the calculation
data for both variables are taken from merra2, and the seasonal cycles of both are removed prior to computing statistics

p d f b y g u e s t o n 1 7 s e p t e m b e r 2 0 2 0 model of koster et al (2000)] are worth emphasizing for this study: (i) the catchment model is also used for merra-2, so that the functional forms fe(w) and fq(w) extracted from merra-2 data holdings also apply to the s2s system, and (ii) during the analysis that underlies the initialization, the precipitation applied to the catchment model is scaled to agree with a gauge data product (reichle et al 2017), so that the initial soil moisture anomalies used in the forecasts are, to first order, realistic

we focus here mainly on the subx forecasts initialized on 5 june, 20 june, 5 july, 20 july, 4 august, and 19 august during each of the years between 1999 and 2015. this provides us with 102 independent warm-season (for conus) forecast periods, each period covering forecast days 16-30. we focus specifically on the average evapotranspiration rates and t2m values produced in each forecast, averaging their 16-30-day values across the forecast's four ensemble members after regridding the 0.58 3 0.58 forecast data onto the 0.6258 3 0.58 grid used for merra-2 diagnostic products

verification data and skill metrics for the purposes of evaluating the subx et forecasts and the projet estimates produced with the simple modeling framework, we will utilize as ''observations'' the merra-2 et product
in some ways this is inappropriate, since a reanalysis's et product is strongly influenced by the land model underlying it, and the same land model is used in both merra-2 and the geos s2s system

in effect, the merra-2 estimates will differ from the subx forecasts only through merra-2's application of year-specific time series of net radiation and gaugecorrected precipitation for each 30-day time period in question

using merra-2 et to evaluate subx et and the projet estimates will accordingly tell us how much of the merra-2 et product is associated with meteorological forcing during that period as opposed to the soil moisture state at the beginning of that period

evaluations against merra-2 t2m data, which, as for et, are limited by the use of a common land model, are supplemented here with evaluations against the independent, fully observations-based cpc t dataset ()
the different estimates arise from the different p and rnet forcing time series used; these time series are extracted from an independent merra-2 period (1980-98)

figures 9a and 9b show a significant difference in subx skill depending on the target, with the subx estimates matching the merra-2 estimates more closely (higher r2 values of ;0.3-0.4) than the cpc estimates (higher r2 values of ;0.2)

the fact that the skill levels are higher when the t2m validation data are taken from merra-2 rather than from the independent cpc station-based dataset indicates that the merra-2 t2m data themselves are significantly influenced by the land model parameterization

7699VEJN.title: 2020_Nguyen_Characterizing a landmark biomass-burning event and its implication for aging.pdf

sentences.sentence: bb activity over the study region was illustrated using modis fire product (mcd14dl) acquired from the nasa fire information for resource management system (firms)
in addition, modis/aqua aerosol optical depth (aod) measured at 550 nm with a spatial resolution is 1×1 was used to exam the bb smoke transport path

calipso data for the study period (13 and 18 march, 2009; daytime data) was obtained via , the nasa merra-2 (merra, version 2) dataset, which implements aerosol reanalysis with nasa satellite data, was applied to our analysis
the aerosol vertical distribution was taken from merra-2 reanalysis product m2i3nvaer (merra-2 inst3_3d_aer_nv) which has 72 vertical levels in global coverage
the spatial resolution and time resolution of merra-2 are 0.5×0.625 and 6 hours, respectively
detailed descriptions of merra-2 can be found in buchard et al (2015) and our previous publication huang et al (2020)

five-day bwts arriving at 8:00 lt to an altitude near labs were calculated using the hybrid single-particle lagrangian integrated trajectory (hysplit) model (draxler and rolph, 2013) with meteorological data obtained from the ncep gdas (gdas), which has a resolution of 1×1. results of bwts and fire distribution 220 221 222 223 224 225 226 227 228 229 230 231 232 233 234 235 236 237 238 239 240 241 242 243 244 from 16 to 20 march 2009 are shown in fig

we defined bb events at labs according to the following criteria: (1) co enhancement of 20% above the monthly mean concentration for at least 12 hours, (2) the 245 246 247 248 249 250 251 252 253 254 255 256 257 258 259 260 261 262 263 264 265 266 267 268 269 correlation (r2) of o3 and co > 0.6, (3) concentration enhancements of at least one other species (pm, hg, o3), and (4) the air mass passed over fire regions and the fire spots were observed by modis/aqua
according to modis true color images, a large area over the indochina peninsula was covered by a light brown color on 15 march, suggesting the presence of smoke produced from bb activities
modis aod and omi ai indicated the eastward transport of bb smoke between 15 and 16 march

DDLF4XSJ.title: 2020_Duc_Spatial-Temporal Pattern of Black Carbon (BC) Emission from Biomass Burning and.pdf

sentences.sentence: 2.1. measurement techniques the bc concentrations analysed in this study were from two sources: the nasa merra, version 2 (merra-2) reanalysis and the aethalometer measurements within nsw dpie air quality monitoring network

satellite data products from modis aqua/terra and lidar data from caliop (cloud-aerosol lidar with orthogonal polarization) instrument on calipso (cloud-aerosol lidar and infrared pathfinder satellite observation) satellite were also used to detect the hot spots of biomass burnings as sources of bc emission and smoke plumes

in our study, hysplit was run at with gdas (gdas) data at a spatial resolution of 0.25. the backward trajectories predicted by hysplit having particles released at 10 m for 24 or 48 h were used to determine the location of biomass burning sources that caused high concentration of bc and pm2.5 as measured at the monitoring sites
2.2.3. the merra-2 reanalysis bc predicted surface concentration from the global merra-2 reanalysis model was used to study the bc spatial distribution across nsw

the merra-2 reanalysis data produced by nasa's global modelling and assimilation office (gmao) were downloaded from ?&path=/geos-5. the bc concentrations at the surface level, as a component of the merra aerosol reanalysis (merraero) with a 0.5-degree spatial resolution and 3-h interval, were extracted

the merraero is based on geos-5 which is radiatively coupled to the goddard chemistry, aerosol, radiation and transport (gocart) aerosol module and includes assimilation of aerosol optical depth (aod) from the modis sensor aboard the aqua/terra satellites, ground-based aeronet aod data
the geos-5 gocart module, as described in , includes 15 aerosol tracers, such as dust, sea salt, sulphate, black and organic carbon, o3, co and co2
merra-2 aerosol assimilation data product for geos-5 allows one to distinguish among various emission sources of bc

figure 2a shows the bc one-month average surface mass concentration assimilation data from merra-2 over south-eastern australia in may 2018. figure 2b shows the biomass burning during may 2018 occurred near sydney, and in the hinterland area near the queensland-new south wales border

the bc anthropogenic emission pattern from merra-2 assimilation data model (figure 2c) is similar to that from edgar-htap global anthropogenic black carbon (bc) emission database, as shown in figure 2d

2. (a) bc one-month average surface mass concentration (may 2018); (b) bc emission from biomass burning sources; (c) bc emission from anthropogenic sources as provided from merra-2 of geos-5 model; and (d) edgar-htap global anthropogenic black carbon (bc) emission (g/m3 m/s) at 15 km × 15 km resolution
figure 9 shows the bc concentration on 4 may 2015 at 15:00 aest as predicted from merra

10. (a) biomass burning hot spots and smoke plumes in the blue mountains west of sydney and newcastle as detected by modis satellites on 6 may 2016; and (b) hourly bc concentration as measured by aethalometer at chullora and newcastle from 1 to 30 may 2016. the biomass burning for hazardous reduction burnings occurred during 6-7 and 17-18 may 2016. three major biomass burnings were conducted by the rural fire service (rfs) outside the sydney basin: one in the blue mountains near katoomba-wentworth falls started during 5-7 may; another at the southwest of the first fire, near wallacia and warragamba dam at the edge of the sydney basin, during 6-7 may; and the last in the north of the sydney basin located in the national park (pisgah ridge) and west of the lower hunter area during 6-8 may

15. hysplit ensemble backward trajectories overlaid on modis aqua/terra satellite images with hot spots (small red dots) for 48 h from newcastle at 10-m height on: (a) 5 may 2016 08:00 aest; (b) 6 may 2016 08:00 aest; and (c) 7 may 2016 08:00 aest

figure 16 shows the spatial pattern of bc extinction aot (aerosol optical thickness) and bc surface mass concentration average at resolution of 0.5 × 0.625 for may 2016 as predicted by merra model (obtained from giovanni online )
observed measurements of total aod on modis aqua satellite at lower resolution of 1 × 1 averaged over the same period in figure 17 also show corresponding high bc aod with hrb areas near sydney

16. (a) time averaged map (may 2016) of black carbon extinction aot 550 nm monthly 0.5 × 0.625 (merra-2 model m2tmnxaer v5.12.4); and (b) time averaged map of black carbon surface mass concentration monthly 0.5 × 0.625 (merra-2 model m2tmnxaer v5.12.4) kgm3. high monthly values of bc column aot and surface concentration in the blue mountains and the riverina region can be seen

figure 17. time averaged map of aod 550 nm (deep blue, land-only) daily 1 (modis-aqua myd08_d3 v6.1) for the period 4-7 may 2016. lidar data from calipso instrument on caliop satellite can be used to detect the smoke aerosols
the merra-2 bc and aerosol assimilation system from geos-5 model and calipso satellite product are also valuable to verify the bc temporal and spatial pattern as predicted from model such as wrf-chem
however, the merra-2 bc prediction does not correspond well with observations in our case studies
acknowledgments: the merra-2 data used in this study/project were provided by the global modeling and assimilation office (gmao) at nasa goddard space flight center
